You’ve decided to quit Twitter. Here’s what you can use to replace it.Heather Kelly9/29/2022

The best alternatives to Twitter for people who don't want to stay on the Elon Musk-owned site.

Tech in Your LifeRead

class="wpds-c-cYdRxM wpds-c-cYdRxM-iPJLV-css font-copy">Twitter has a new billionaire owner with big plans. For many loyal users of the 16-year old site, <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/technology/2022/10/27/twitter-elon-musk/?itid=lk_inline_manual_2" target=_blank>Elon Musk’s takeover</a> is a sign it’s time to use Twitter less or leave it altogether.</p></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-qa="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="wpds-c-cYdRxM wpds-c-cYdRxM-iPJLV-css font-copy">The fast-moving feed of news, commentary and arguments has already seen some changes, including a <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/technology/2022/10/28/musk-twitter-racist-posts/?itid=lk_inline_manual_3" target=_blank>rise in hate speech</a>. Musk has made it clear that <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/technology/2022/10/05/twitter-elon-musk-future-trump/?itid=lk_inline_manual_3" target=_blank>he intends to overhaul</a> the site. <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/technology/2022/10/20/musk-twitter-acquisition-staff-cuts/?itid=lk_inline_manual_3" target=_blank>Massive job cuts</a> and his own position on <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/technology/2022/05/16/twitter-elon-musk-india/?itid=lk_inline_manual_3" target=_blank>free speech</a> could lead to more widespread <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/technology/2022/04/25/online-harassment-guide/?itid=lk_inline_manual_3" target=_blank>harassment</a> and <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/technology/2022/02/24/tips-avoid-misinformation-ukraine/?itid=lk_inline_manual_3" target=_blank>misinformation</a>.<b> </b>Musk has also suggested that he would allow former president Donald Trump back on the site.</p></div></div><div></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><div class=" mb-md hide-for-print" data-qa="subscribe-promo"><div media company, firing several key executives. (Video: Jonathan Baran/The Washington Post)</div></figcaption></figure></div></div></div></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-qa="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="wpds-c-cYdRxM wpds-c-cYdRxM-iPJLV-css font-copy">A number of companies are scrambling to fill the potential void. After the sale closed, a surge of people said they were moving to <a href="https://joinmastodon.org/" target=_blank>Mastodon</a>, an open-source alternative that has tried to catch on as a less toxic Twitter for years. Mastodon gained<b> </b>22,139 new accounts this past week and 10,801 in the day after Musk took over, said <a href="https://mastodon.social/@Gargron/109247989447397169" target=_blank>Mastodon chief executive Eugen Rochko</a>. The site now has more than 380,000 monthly active users, while Twitter has 237.8 million daily active users.</p></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><div class="cb dn db-ns" data-qa="article-body-ad"><div aria-hidden="true" class="hide-for-print relative flex justify-center content-box items-center b bh mb-md mt-none pt-lg pb-lg" style="min-height:250px;border-top-color:;border-bottom-color:"><div class="center absolute w-100 border-box" style="top:"><div class="dib gray-dark pl-xs pr-xs font-sans-serif light font-xxxxs lh-md" style="--primary-border-color:"></div></div><div data-testid="placeholder-box" class="w-100 h-100 absolute flex flex-column justify-center border-box bg-offwhite" style="width:300px;height:250px"><div class="flex flex-column justify-center font-sans-serif center font-xxs light gray-dark lh-md"><div>Advertisement</div></div></div></div></div></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><div class="cb db dn-ns" data-qa="article-body-ad"><div aria-hidden="true" class="hide-for-print relative flex justify-center content-box items-center b bh mb-md mt-sm pt-sm pb-sm" style="min-height:250px;border-top-color:;border-bottom-color:"><div class="center absolute w-100 border-box" style="top:"><div class="dib gray-dark pl-xs pr-xs font-sans-serif light font-xxxxs lh-md" style="--primary-border-color:"></div></div><div data-testid="placeholder-box" class="w-100 h-100 absolute flex flex-column justify-center border-box bg-offwhite" style="width:300px;height:250px"><div class="flex flex-column justify-center font-sans-serif center font-xxs light gray-dark lh-md"></div></div></div></div></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-qa="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="wpds-c-cYdRxM wpds-c-cYdRxM-iPJLV-css font-copy">Even if all of Twitter agrees to relocate, there is no one exact copy or one app that will hit all the same spots. <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/technology/2021/10/12/leave-facebook-alternatives/?itid=lk_inline_manual_9" target=_blank>As with Facebook</a>, ditching Twitter can mean scattering your online presence across multiple other apps. Leaving Twitter could also mean cutting things out of your online life permanently, like late-night doomscrolling or arguing with strangers online for sport. And maybe, just maybe, that’s okay.</p></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-qa="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="wpds-c-cYdRxM wpds-c-cYdRxM-iPJLV-css font-copy">Here are the options you can consider.</p></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p><span class="font--article-body font-copy hide-for-print ma-0 pb-md db italic interstitial"><a data-qa="interstitial-link" href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/technology/interactive/2021/privacy-settings-guide/?itid=lk_interstitial_manual_11">Privacy Reset: A guide to the important settings you should change now</a></span></p></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><h3 data-qa="article-header" class=" pb-sm pt-lgmod" id="5Y2RUWPBVRHTFCASL7X4NBUTG4"><div>Read the news</div></h3></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-qa="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="wpds-c-cYdRxM wpds-c-cYdRxM-iPJLV-css font-copy">For many users, Twitter is the place they see the news happening in real time. Instead, put a news aggregation app on the homepage of your phone, like Apple’s News app or Google News. Both include a wide selection of outlets and local news sources, which can be the first to report on events in their areas like shootings or disasters. Switching to traditional news outlets has the added bonus of decreasing the risk of misinformation, which can spread on Twitter during breaking news events.</p></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><div class="cb dn db-ns" data-qa="article-body-ad"><div aria-hidden="true" class="hide-for-print relative flex justify-center content-box items-center b bh mb-md mt-none pt-lg pb-lg" style="min-height:250px;border-top-color:;border-bottom-color:"><div class="center absolute w-100 border-box" style="top:"><div class="dib gray-dark pl-xs pr-xs font-sans-serif light font-xxxxs lh-md" style="--primary-border-color:"></div></div><div data-testid="placeholder-box" class="w-100 h-100 absolute flex flex-column justify-center border-box bg-offwhite" style="width:300px;height:250px"><div class="flex flex-column justify-center font-sans-serif center font-xxs light gray-dark lh-md"><div>Advertisement</div></div></div></div></div></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><div class="cb db dn-ns" data-qa="article-body-ad"><div aria-hidden="true" class="hide-for-print relative flex justify-center content-box items-center b bh mb-md mt-sm pt-sm pb-sm" style="min-height:250px;border-top-color:;border-bottom-color:"><div class="center absolute w-100 border-box" style="top:"><div class="dib gray-dark pl-xs pr-xs font-sans-serif light font-xxxxs lh-md" style="--primary-border-color:"></div></div><div data-testid="placeholder-box" class="w-100 h-100 absolute flex flex-column justify-center border-box bg-offwhite" style="width:300px;height:250px"><div class="flex flex-column justify-center font-sans-serif center font-xxs light gray-dark lh-md"></div></div></div></div></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-qa="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="wpds-c-cYdRxM wpds-c-cYdRxM-iPJLV-css font-copy">If you prefer to make your own list of outlets, like you do on Twitter, try an RSS reader. Use an app like Feedly, Newsify or Inoreader. If you specifically enjoy the messy arguments over news stories between regular Twitter patrons, any news publication’s comment section should fill that void.</p></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><h3 data-qa="article-header" class=" pb-sm pt-lgmod" id="NJS27IZCKNA6DCA2BMHRZQAOOA"><div>Get expertise and entertainment</div></h3></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-qa="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="wpds-c-cYdRxM wpds-c-cYdRxM-iPJLV-css font-copy">One of the delights of Twitter is that you can read the thoughts of fascinating people for free. Academics, law experts, reporters, comics, and people who have devoted their life to niche topics are all sharing their brilliance in an accessible way. Luckily, many are posting those same thoughts, in more depth, other places.</p></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><div class="cb db dn-ns" data-qa="article-body-ad"><div aria-hidden="true" class="hide-for-print relative flex justify-center content-box items-center b bh mb-md mt-sm pt-sm pb-sm" style="min-height:250px;border-top-color:;border-bottom-color:"><div class="center absolute w-100 border-box" style="top:"><div class="dib gray-dark pl-xs pr-xs font-sans-serif light font-xxxxs lh-md" style="--primary-border-color:"></div></div><div data-testid="placeholder-box" class="w-100 h-100 absolute flex flex-column justify-center border-box bg-offwhite" style="width:300px;height:250px"><div class="flex flex-column justify-center font-sans-serif center font-xxs light gray-dark lh-md"></div></div></div></div></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-qa="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="wpds-c-cYdRxM wpds-c-cYdRxM-iPJLV-css font-copy">Sign up for newsletters. Many big Twitter personalities have longer-form offerings, published through their employers or independently on <a href="https://substack.com/" target=_blank>Substack</a> or <a href="https://medium.com/" target=_blank>Medium</a>.<b> </b>You can also support creators on sites like <a href="http://patreon.com/" target=_blank>Patreon</a> and <a href="http://ko-fi.com/" target=_blank>Ko-fi</a>, which let you pay different amounts for access to their content. Follow them on the other big social media sites, like Instagram, TikTok, YouTube and LinkedIn. Finally, subscribe to podcasts featuring the same kind of smart, funny and informative people you find on Twitter.</p></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><h3 data-qa="article-header" class=" pb-sm pt-lgmod" id="CNJKD33UMJGFTOQ6JUPOZV3VIM"><div>Forge personal relationships</div></h3></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-qa="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="wpds-c-cYdRxM wpds-c-cYdRxM-iPJLV-css font-copy">People have found lasting friendships, even fallen in love and gotten married, over Twitter. If you already established relationships with other Twitter users, make sure you have another way to reach them, like <a href="https://www.whatsapp.com/" target="_blank">WhatsApp</a>, <a href="https://signal.org/en/" target="_blank">Signal</a> or Instagram. If you have a group of friends, it was probably time to fire up a <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/technology/2022/04/14/texting-etiquette-101/?itid=lk_inline_manual_22" target="_blank">group chat </a>anyway.</p></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><div class="cb dn db-ns" data-qa="article-body-ad"><div aria-hidden="true" class="hide-for-print relative flex justify-center content-box items-center b bh mb-md mt-none pt-lg pb-lg" style="min-height:250px;border-top-color:;border-bottom-color:"><div class="center absolute w-100 border-box" style="top:"><div class="dib gray-dark pl-xs pr-xs font-sans-serif light font-xxxxs lh-md" style="--primary-border-color:"></div></div><div data-testid="placeholder-box" class="w-100 h-100 absolute flex flex-column justify-center border-box bg-offwhite" style="width:300px;height:250px"><div class="flex flex-column justify-center font-sans-serif center font-xxs light gray-dark lh-md"><div>Advertisement</div></div></div></div></div></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><div class="cb db dn-ns" data-qa="article-body-ad"><div aria-hidden="true" class="hide-for-print relative flex justify-center content-box items-center b bh mb-md mt-sm pt-sm pb-sm" style="min-height:250px;border-top-color:;border-bottom-color:"><div class="center absolute w-100 border-box" style="top:"><div class="dib gray-dark pl-xs pr-xs font-sans-serif light font-xxxxs lh-md" style="--primary-border-color:"></div></div><div data-testid="placeholder-box" class="w-100 h-100 absolute flex flex-column justify-center border-box bg-offwhite" style="width:300px;height:250px"><div class="flex flex-column justify-center font-sans-serif center font-xxs light gray-dark lh-md"></div></div></div></div></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-qa="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="wpds-c-cYdRxM wpds-c-cYdRxM-iPJLV-css font-copy">As for making more of these connections, that’s harder. Send emails or direct messages to people whose posts you like on other sites. When you join other sites like <a href="https://www.reddit.com/" target=_blank>Reddit</a>, look for communities of people with similar interests and use direct messages or replies to strike up friendly conversations. Some dating sites have launched platonic versions of their apps specifically for meeting friends, including <a href="https://bumble.com/bff" target=_blank>Bumble BFF</a>, <a href="http://meetup.com/" target=_blank>Meetup</a> and <a href="https://frienderapp.com/" target=_blank>Friender</a>.</p></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><h3 data-qa="article-header" class=" pb-sm pt-lgmod" id="KEMJ4247ZJBF3LMOCFSOOKIKYU"><div>Be part of a community</div></h3></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-qa="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="wpds-c-cYdRxM wpds-c-cYdRxM-iPJLV-css font-copy">To find larger groups of people with similar interests, check out <a href="https://www.facebook.com/groups/explore/" target=_blank>Facebook groups</a>, join <a href="http://reddit.com/" target=_blank>subreddits</a> about the topics you’re most interested in, find relevant <a href="http://discord.com/" target=_blank>Discord</a> groups or see if there’s a similar group on <a href="https://joinmastodon.org/" target=_blank>Mastodon</a>. You can test out an app called <a href="https://counter.social/index.html" target=_blank>CounterSocial</a> that has a similar feel to Twitter. There’s a high chance all of your interests already have a thriving community on <a href="http://tiktok.com/" target=_blank>TikTok</a> and <a href="http://youtube.com/" target=_blank>YouTube</a>, where you can participate in comments if you’re not into posting videos yourself. If you are trying to find a specific community, look at their last tweets and see if prominent members have said where they’ll be next. If you don’t see the group you want thriving anywhere yet, go ahead and start it yourself.</p></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><h3 data-qa="article-header" class=" pb-sm pt-lgmod" id="SYQV7W7YURBD5EQVJRWNPTCIP4"><div>Get updates in an emergency</div></h3></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-qa="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="wpds-c-cYdRxM wpds-c-cYdRxM-iPJLV-css font-copy">Federal and local agencies use Twitter to post updates about emergencies, like road closings from floods, shelter-in-place orders during shootings and evacuation updates for wildfires. You can follow the agencies on Facebook instead, but your best bet is to make sure you are getting alerts pushed directly to you on your phone.</p></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p><span class="font--article-body font-copy hide-for-print ma-0 pb-md db italic interstitial"><a data-qa="interstitial-link" href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/technology/2022/02/11/emergency-alerts-smartphones/?itid=lk_interstitial_manual_30">How to never miss an emergency alert from shootings to wildfires</a></span></p></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-qa="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="wpds-c-cYdRxM wpds-c-cYdRxM-iPJLV-css font-copy">Check your phone settings to see what wireless emergency alerts you’re getting, like Amber Alerts. Subscribe to your school or workplace alert systems, and find local alerts by looking up your state, city or county agencies. A number of them use text-based emergency alert system <a href="http://nixle.com/" target=_blank>Nixle</a> (to sign up, text your Zip code to 888777).</p></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><div class="cb dn db-ns" data-qa="article-body-ad"><div aria-hidden="true" class="hide-for-print relative flex justify-center content-box items-center b bh mb-md mt-none pt-lg pb-lg" style="min-height:250px;border-top-color:;border-bottom-color:"><div class="center absolute w-100 border-box" style="top:"><div class="dib gray-dark pl-xs pr-xs font-sans-serif light font-xxxxs lh-md" style="--primary-border-color:"></div></div><div data-testid="placeholder-box" class="w-100 h-100 absolute flex flex-column justify-center border-box bg-offwhite" style="width:300px;height:250px"><div class="flex flex-column justify-center font-sans-serif center font-xxs light gray-dark lh-md"><div>Advertisement</div></div></div></div></div></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><div class="cb db dn-ns" data-qa="article-body-ad"><div aria-hidden="true" class="hide-for-print relative flex justify-center content-box items-center b bh mb-md mt-sm pt-sm pb-sm" style="min-height:250px;border-top-color:;border-bottom-color:"><div class="center absolute w-100 border-box" style="top:"><div class="dib gray-dark pl-xs pr-xs font-sans-serif light font-xxxxs lh-md" style="--primary-border-color:"></div></div><div data-testid="placeholder-box" class="w-100 h-100 absolute flex flex-column justify-center border-box bg-offwhite" style="width:300px;height:250px"><div class="flex flex-column justify-center font-sans-serif center font-xxs light gray-dark lh-md"></div></div></div></div></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-qa="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="wpds-c-cYdRxM wpds-c-cYdRxM-iPJLV-css font-copy">Finally, you can dive into the controversial world of neighborhood crime apps, like <a href="https://citizen.com/" target=_blank>Citizen</a> and Amazon’s <a href="https://ring.com/neighbors" target=_blank>Neighbors</a> app. They let you follow events as they happen in your area with updates from people on the scene, and many local agencies are already on them. (Amazon founder Jeff Bezos owns The Washington Post.)</p></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><h3 data-qa="article-header" class=" pb-sm pt-lgmod" id="PC6RFFD2QBD6RGGKMD64LAFHBM"><div>Do some networking</div></h3></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-qa="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="wpds-c-cYdRxM wpds-c-cYdRxM-iPJLV-css font-copy">It seems that for as long as job hunting and corporate jargon exist, <a href="http://linkedin.com/" target=_blank>LinkedIn</a> will thrive. You’re probably already on LinkedIn, so just give your profile a polish and start posting or sharing what you’re working on there.</p></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><h3 data-qa="article-header" class=" pb-sm pt-lgmod" id="JY4EM57MWZEOVMFIU2MOBRTXSU"><div>Listen to live audio</div></h3></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-qa="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="wpds-c-cYdRxM wpds-c-cYdRxM-iPJLV-css font-copy">An exodus from Twitter could be the best thing to happen to Clubhouse, the audio chatroom app that had a moment during the pandemic. Twitter copied Clubhouse with its Twitter Spaces feature, which has been a hit with many users. If you’re leaving Twitter, <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/technology/2021/02/10/what-is-clubhouse-faq/?itid=lk_inline_manual_38" target=_blank>Clubhouse</a> is still around and hosting round-the-clock chatrooms.</p></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><h3 data-qa="article-header" class=" pb-sm pt-lgmod" id="I7VUPA5E7NFUTPCKWCNSKTMMQA"><div>Enjoy nonstop scrolling</div></h3></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-qa="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="wpds-c-cYdRxM wpds-c-cYdRxM-iPJLV-css font-copy">TikTok has elevated mindless scrolling to an art form. If you use Twitter as a way to kill time or unwind, TikTok is the best replacement. You can see similar addictive video content on<a href="https://about.instagram.com/features/reels" target="_blank"> Instagram Reels</a>, albeit a couple days or weeks later. If your Twitter scrolling is more of a problem than an enjoyable way to pass time, consider <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/technology/2019/11/26/e-books-libraries-are-huge-hit-leading-long-waits-reader-hacks-worried-publishers/?itid=lk_inline_manual_40" target="_blank">checking out e-books</a> from your local library to read on your phone instead. You get the same feel of flipping through nonstop text on your screen free, but with less anxiety.</p></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><h3 data-qa="article-header" class=" pb-sm pt-lgmod" id="SYQV7W7YURBD5EQVJRWNPTCIP4"><div>Be smart about trying new apps</div></h3></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-qa="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="wpds-c-cYdRxM wpds-c-cYdRxM-iPJLV-css font-copy">When choosing new social networks or apps to test out, don’t blindly trust smaller companies with your data or personal information. Remember that larger alternatives like Facebook and TikTok come with their own ethical and privacy issues. To stay safe, avoid giving apps access to sensitive information like <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/technology/2021/07/15/contacts-sharing-privacy/?itid=lk_inline_manual_42" target="_blank">your contacts</a> (they will ask repeatedly). Check<a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/technology/interactive/2021/privacy-settings-guide/?itid=lk_inline_manual_42" target="_blank"> all of your privacy settings</a>, both in the app on your smartphone’s settings. Sign up with an alias email address and use a <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/technology/2021/12/16/secure-password-guide/?itid=lk_inline_manual_42" target="_blank">strong password</a> and multi-factor authentication when you can.</p></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><h3 data-qa="article-header" class=" pb-sm pt-lgmod" id="ERE6EMJ4WNEF3HEZACDF5F6BNI"><div>Stick around but protect your data</div></h3></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-qa="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="wpds-c-cYdRxM wpds-c-cYdRxM-iPJLV-css font-copy">If you want to wait and see what happens, you can do it while minimizing any potential <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/technology/2022/01/19/twitter-privacy-settings/?itid=lk_inline_manual_44" target=_blank>privacy risks</a> posed by new management or a drop in moderation. You can even make yourself a ghost on the app without having to fully leave it.</p></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p><span class="font--article-body font-copy hide-for-print ma-0 pb-md db italic interstitial"><a data-qa="interstitial-link" href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/technology/2022/04/26/twitter-musk-data-protect/?itid=lk_interstitial_manual_45">How to lock down your Twitter data, or leave, as Musk takes over</a></span></p></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-qa="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="wpds-c-cYdRxM wpds-c-cYdRxM-iPJLV-css font-copy">If you use Twitter anonymously to communicate sensitive information, or worry about online harassment, do these things immediately: Back up all your tweets and follow lists, delete sensitive DMs (both sides have to delete it), delete old tweets, and lock down privacy and anti-harassment settings.</p></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-qa="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="wpds-c-cYdRxM wpds-c-cYdRxM-iPJLV-css font-copy">We walk you through each of these steps <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/technology/2022/04/26/twitter-musk-data-protect/?itid=lk_inline_manual_47" target=_blank>in this guide</a>. Even if you aren’t worried about your Twitter presence, you should export a copy of your Twitter data now so you have a list of people you follow, before they leave.</p></div><div class="wpds-c-jjHkyS hide-for-print"><div data-qa="content" class="wpds-c-bBtBOR wpds-c-bBtBOR-iPJLV-css"><h3 data-qa="linkbox-headline" class="wpds-c-jtAZFm">Help Desk: Making tech work for you</h3><p class="wpds-c-eynqHn"><a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/personal-tech/"><b>Help Desk</b></a> is a destination built for readers looking to better understand and take control of the technology used in everyday life.</p><p class="wpds-c-eynqHn"><b>Go deeper:</b> <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/personal-tech/tech-your-life/">Tech in Your Life</a> | <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/personal-tech/tech-work/">Tech at Work</a> | <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/personal-tech/data-privacy/">Your Data and Privacy</a> | <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/personal-tech/internet-access/" target=_blank>Internet Access</a> | <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/personal-tech/whats-new/">What’s New</a> | <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/personal-tech/ethical-issues/">Ethical Issues</a></p><p class="wpds-c-eynqHn"><b>Data and Privacy:</b> <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/technology/interactive/2021/privacy-settings-guide/" target=_blank><b>A guide to every privacy setting you should change now</b></a>. We have gone through the<b> </b>settings for the most popular (and problematic) services to give you recommendations. <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/technology/2021/09/23/google-privacy-settings/" target=_blank>Google</a> | <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/technology/2021/09/23/amazon-privacy-settings/" target=_blank>Amazon</a> | <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/technology/2021/09/23/facebook-privacy-settings/" target=_blank>Facebook</a> | <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/technology/2021/09/23/venmo-privacy-settings/" target=_blank>Venmo</a> | <a For many loyal users of the 16-year old site, \u003ca href=\"https://www.washingtonpost.com/technology/2022/10/27/twitter-elon-musk/\" target=_blank\u003eElon Musk’s takeover\u003c/a\u003e is a sign it’s time to use Twitter less or leave it altogether.","type":"text","originalIdx":1},{"_id":"EG2ORUMY4ZBHNL4P4QPHVQTEIY","additional_properties":{},"content":"The fast-moving feed of news, commentary and arguments has already seen some changes, including a \u003ca href=\"https://www.washingtonpost.com/technology/2022/10/28/musk-twitter-racist-posts/\" target=_blank\u003erise in hate speech\u003c/a\u003e. Musk has made it clear that \u003ca href=\"https://www.washingtonpost.com/technology/2022/10/05/twitter-elon-musk-future-trump/\" target=_blank\u003ehe intends to overhaul\u003c/a\u003e the site. \u003ca href=\"https://www.washingtonpost.com/technology/2022/10/20/musk-twitter-acquisition-staff-cuts/\" target=_blank\u003eMassive job cuts\u003c/a\u003e and his own position on \u003ca href=\"https://www.washingtonpost.com/technology/2022/05/16/twitter-elon-musk-india/\" target=_blank\u003efree speech\u003c/a\u003e could lead to more widespread \u003ca href=\"https://www.washingtonpost.com/technology/2022/04/25/online-harassment-guide/\" target=_blank\u003eharassment\u003c/a\u003e and \u003ca href=\"https://www.washingtonpost.com/technology/2022/02/24/tips-avoid-misinformation-ukraine/\" target=_blank\u003emisinformation\u003c/a\u003e.\u003cb\u003e \u003c/b\u003eMusk has also suggested that he would allow former president Donald Trump back on the site.","type":"text","originalIdx":2},{"_id":"c07299d3-d661-4871-b0ad-75f7a455c8aa","additional_properties":{"embedContinuousPlay":true},"canonical_url":"/video/technology/elon-musks-ownership-of-twitter-begins/2022/10/27/c07299d3-d661-4871-b0ad-75f7a455c8aa_video.html","credits":{"by":[{"name":"Jonathan Baran","url":"https://www.washingtonpost.com/people/jonathan-baran/","additional_properties":{"original":{"expertise":"Video reporter and editor covering technology, business and culture.","image":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/arc-authors/washpost/03f3320e-f5cb-4ecb-bd92-77e510c6ecc3.png"}}}]},"credits_caption_display":"On Oct. 27, Elon Musk completed his purchase of Twitter and began taking control of the social media company, firing several key executives. (Video: Jonathan Baran/The Washington Post)","display_date":"2022-10-28T01:47:29.000Z","distributor":{"category":"staff"},"headlines":{"basic":"Elon Musk's ownership of Twitter begins"},"promo_image":{"url":"https://d1i4t8bqe7zgj6.cloudfront.net/10-28-2022/t_d2d26c7967994ad3b00c557fd2aa5d8f_name_20221024_ELONBUYSTWITTER.png"},"related_content":{"basic":[{"_id":"2YKVIXK6CJCZ3F4K7WZVXDNW7E","additional_properties":{"canonical_url":"/technology/2022/10/27/twitter-elon-musk/","title":"Top Twitter executives fired as Elon Musk takeover begins"},"referent":{"id":"2YKVIXK6CJCZ3F4K7WZVXDNW7E","provider":"","type":"story"},"type":"reference"},{"_id":"3LU7IQFH6FBUBA2FAREAPB3MBQ","additional_properties":{"canonical_url":"/technology/2022/10/20/musk-twitter-acquisition-staff-cuts/","title":"Documents detail plans to gut Twitter’s workforce"},"referent":{"id":"3LU7IQFH6FBUBA2FAREAPB3MBQ","provider":"","type":"story"},"type":"reference"},{"_id":"VBXZI5OQ65HSTJG7AXLH7PGDPI","additional_properties":{"canonical_url":"/technology/2022/06/01/elon-musk-twitter-investors/","title":"Elon Musk lines up growing list of investors to take over Twitter"},"referent":{"id":"VBXZI5OQ65HSTJG7AXLH7PGDPI","provider":"","type":"story"},"type":"reference"}],"redirect":[]},"streams":[{"height":180,"width":320},{"height":360,"width":640},{"height":360,"width":640},{"height":480,"width":854},{"height":1080,"width":1920},{"height":1080,"width":1920},{"height":180,"width":320},{"height":360,"width":640},{"height":480,"width":854},{"height":720,"width":1280},{"height":1080,"width":1920}],"taxonomy":{"tags":[{"text":"breaking-news-video"},{"text":"twitter"}]},"type":"video","originalIdx":3},{"_id":"JKTN4IG3WFGDPH74ZC6ULJQLCI","additional_properties":{},"content":"A number of companies are scrambling to fill the potential void. After the sale closed, a surge of people said they were moving to \u003ca href=\"https://joinmastodon.org/\" target=_blank\u003eMastodon\u003c/a\u003e, an open-source alternative that has tried to catch on as a less toxic Twitter for years. Mastodon gained\u003cb\u003e \u003c/b\u003e22,139 new accounts this past week and 10,801 in the day after Musk took over, said \u003ca href=\"https://mastodon.social/@Gargron/109247989447397169\" target=_blank\u003eMastodon chief executive Eugen Rochko\u003c/a\u003e. The site now has more than 380,000 monthly active users, while Twitter has 237.8 million daily active users.","type":"text","originalIdx":4},{"_id":"6QT7SZINVJBCBI46XJQMUYSL2M","additional_properties":{},"content":"Even if all of Twitter agrees to relocate, there is no one exact copy or one app that will hit all the same spots. \u003ca href=\"https://www.washingtonpost.com/technology/2021/10/12/leave-facebook-alternatives/\" target=_blank\u003eAs with Facebook\u003c/a\u003e, ditching Twitter can mean scattering your online presence across multiple other apps. Leaving Twitter could also mean cutting things out of your online life permanently, like late-night doomscrolling or arguing with strangers online for sport. And maybe, just maybe, that’s okay.","type":"text","originalIdx":5},{"_id":"DQ5TF5ANRZFKTAA4C2DRRGXLBA","additional_properties":{},"content":"Here are the options you can consider.","type":"text","originalIdx":6},{"_id":"Q735E5JP5BCQLLOZDGJQE5SXEM","additional_properties":{},"content":"Privacy Reset: A guide to the important settings you should change now","type":"interstitial_link","url":"https://www.washingtonpost.com/technology/interactive/2021/privacy-settings-guide/","originalIdx":7},{"_id":"5Y2RUWPBVRHTFCASL7X4NBUTG4","additional_properties":{},"content":"Read the news","level":3,"type":"header","originalIdx":8},{"_id":"F2MP4YS5GBA37JJ2QWIF6GIEUQ","additional_properties":{},"content":"For many users, Twitter is the place they see the news happening in real time. Instead, put a news aggregation app on the homepage of your phone, like Apple’s News app or Google News. Both include a wide selection of outlets and local news sources, which can be the first to report on events in their areas like shootings or disasters. Switching to traditional news outlets has the added bonus of decreasing the risk of misinformation, which can spread on Twitter during breaking news events.","type":"text","originalIdx":9},{"_id":"4U6QSMO5W5BO5CRHWLX5BFWATQ","additional_properties":{},"content":"If you prefer to make your own list of outlets, like you do on Twitter, try an RSS reader. Use an app like Feedly, Newsify or Inoreader. If you specifically enjoy the messy arguments over news stories between regular Twitter patrons, any news publication’s comment section should fill that void.","type":"text","originalIdx":10},{"_id":"NJS27IZCKNA6DCA2BMHRZQAOOA","additional_properties":{},"content":"Get expertise and entertainment","level":3,"type":"header","originalIdx":11},{"_id":"Y25A5KT3VBCHBIWC3X4JZPUNLI","additional_properties":{},"content":"One of the delights of Twitter is that you can read the thoughts of fascinating people for free. Academics, law experts, reporters, comics, and people who have devoted their life to niche topics are all sharing their brilliance in an accessible way. Luckily, many are posting those same thoughts, in more depth, other places.","type":"text","originalIdx":12},{"_id":"5XQXJRGVHNAZXIVB54KGEJUA5E","additional_properties":{},"content":"Sign up for newsletters. Many big Twitter personalities have longer-form offerings, published through their employers or independently on \u003ca href=\"https://substack.com/\" target=_blank\u003eSubstack\u003c/a\u003e or \u003ca href=\"https://medium.com/\" target=_blank\u003eMedium\u003c/a\u003e.\u003cb\u003e \u003c/b\u003eYou can also support creators on sites like \u003ca href=\"http://patreon.com/\" target=_blank\u003ePatreon\u003c/a\u003e and \u003ca href=\"http://ko-fi.com/\" target=_blank\u003eKo-fi\u003c/a\u003e, which let you pay different amounts for access to their content. Follow them on the other big social media sites, like Instagram, TikTok, YouTube and LinkedIn. Finally, subscribe to podcasts featuring the same kind of smart, funny and informative people you find on Twitter.","type":"text","originalIdx":13},{"_id":"CNJKD33UMJGFTOQ6JUPOZV3VIM","additional_properties":{},"content":"Forge personal relationships","level":3,"type":"header","originalIdx":14},{"_id":"FRZP2ZL4TBC5DMIBPJPOM2GRFY","additional_properties":{},"content":"People have found lasting friendships, even fallen in love and gotten married, over Twitter. If you already established relationships with other Twitter users, make sure you have another way to reach them, like \u003ca href=\"https://www.whatsapp.com/\" target=\"_blank\"\u003eWhatsApp\u003c/a\u003e, \u003ca href=\"https://signal.org/en/\" target=\"_blank\"\u003eSignal\u003c/a\u003e or Instagram. If you have a group of friends, it was probably time to fire up a \u003ca href=\"https://www.washingtonpost.com/technology/2022/04/14/texting-etiquette-101/\" target=\"_blank\"\u003egroup chat \u003c/a\u003eanyway.","type":"text","originalIdx":15},{"_id":"HSV37CUKNBB35NYDIH4VVGFFTQ","additional_properties":{},"content":"As for making more of these connections, that’s harder. Send emails or direct messages to people whose posts you like on other sites. When you join other sites like \u003ca href=\"https://www.reddit.com/\" target=_blank\u003eReddit\u003c/a\u003e, look for communities of people with similar interests and use direct messages or replies to strike up friendly conversations. Some dating sites have launched platonic versions of their apps specifically for meeting friends, including \u003ca href=\"https://bumble.com/bff\" target=_blank\u003eBumble BFF\u003c/a\u003e, \u003ca href=\"http://meetup.com/\" target=_blank\u003eMeetup\u003c/a\u003e and \u003ca href=\"https://frienderapp.com/\" target=_blank\u003eFriender\u003c/a\u003e.","type":"text","originalIdx":16},{"_id":"KEMJ4247ZJBF3LMOCFSOOKIKYU","additional_properties":{},"content":"Be part of a community","level":3,"type":"header","originalIdx":17},{"_id":"EF75RC62MNHHLOE4HGSBVTDNOM","additional_properties":{},"content":"To find larger groups of people with similar interests, check out \u003ca href=\"https://www.facebook.com/groups/explore/\" target=_blank\u003eFacebook groups\u003c/a\u003e, join \u003ca href=\"http://reddit.com/\" target=_blank\u003esubreddits\u003c/a\u003e about the topics you’re most interested in, find relevant \u003ca href=\"http://discord.com/\" target=_blank\u003eDiscord\u003c/a\u003e groups or see if there’s a similar group on \u003ca href=\"https://joinmastodon.org/\" target=_blank\u003eMastodon\u003c/a\u003e. You can test out an app called \u003ca href=\"https://counter.social/index.html\" target=_blank\u003eCounterSocial\u003c/a\u003e that has a similar feel to Twitter. There’s a high chance all of your interests already have a thriving community on \u003ca href=\"http://tiktok.com/\" target=_blank\u003eTikTok\u003c/a\u003e and \u003ca href=\"http://youtube.com/\" target=_blank\u003eYouTube\u003c/a\u003e, where you can participate in comments if you’re not into posting videos yourself. If you are trying to find a specific community, look at their last tweets and see if prominent members have said where they’ll be next. If you don’t see the group you want thriving anywhere yet, go ahead and start it yourself.","type":"text","originalIdx":18},{"_id":"SYQV7W7YURBD5EQVJRWNPTCIP4","additional_properties":{},"content":"Get updates in an emergency","level":3,"type":"header","originalIdx":19},{"_id":"F53NQNYFMJCRDAFAMZQL23OCP4","additional_properties":{},"content":"Federal and local agencies use Twitter to post updates about emergencies, like road closings from floods, shelter-in-place orders during shootings and evacuation updates for wildfires. You can follow the agencies on Facebook instead, but your best bet is to make sure you are getting alerts pushed directly to you on your phone.","type":"text","originalIdx":20},{"_id":"YH44SEL76BHQTJKDSQUW7KH3UY","additional_properties":{},"content":"How to never miss an emergency alert from shootings to wildfires","type":"interstitial_link","url":"https://www.washingtonpost.com/technology/2022/02/11/emergency-alerts-smartphones/","originalIdx":21},{"_id":"YOMD5BX6FRHCDODIYCRVW7YOTM","additional_properties":{},"content":"Check your phone settings to see what wireless emergency alerts you’re getting, like Amber Alerts. Subscribe to your school or workplace alert systems, and find local alerts by looking up your state, city or county agencies. A number of them use text-based emergency alert system \u003ca href=\"http://nixle.com/\" target=_blank\u003eNixle\u003c/a\u003e (to sign up, text your Zip code to 888777).","type":"text","originalIdx":22},{"_id":"6WYGXJNO3VBX5BJUUTXSNBHBTA","additional_properties":{},"content":"Finally, you can dive into the controversial world of neighborhood crime apps, like \u003ca href=\"https://citizen.com/\" target=_blank\u003eCitizen\u003c/a\u003e and Amazon’s \u003ca href=\"https://ring.com/neighbors\" target=_blank\u003eNeighbors\u003c/a\u003e app. They let you follow events as they happen in your area with updates from people on the scene, and many local agencies are already on them. (Amazon founder Jeff Bezos owns The Washington Post.)","type":"text","originalIdx":23},{"_id":"PC6RFFD2QBD6RGGKMD64LAFHBM","additional_properties":{},"content":"Do some networking","level":3,"type":"header","originalIdx":24},{"_id":"TYO4AXQGCZACDO22U6U576KC7Y","additional_properties":{},"content":"It seems that for as long as job hunting and corporate jargon exist, \u003ca href=\"http://linkedin.com/\" target=_blank\u003eLinkedIn\u003c/a\u003e will thrive. You’re probably already on LinkedIn, so just give your profile a polish and start posting or sharing what you’re working on there.","type":"text","originalIdx":25},{"_id":"JY4EM57MWZEOVMFIU2MOBRTXSU","additional_properties":{},"content":"Listen to live audio","level":3,"type":"header","originalIdx":26},{"_id":"URQ7UMNUUJBIZP5LX5A3ULEDL4","additional_properties":{},"content":"An exodus from Twitter could be the best thing to happen to Clubhouse, the audio chatroom app that had a moment during the pandemic. Twitter copied Clubhouse with its Twitter Spaces feature, which has been a hit with many users. If you’re leaving Twitter, \u003ca href=\"https://www.washingtonpost.com/technology/2021/02/10/what-is-clubhouse-faq/\" target=_blank\u003eClubhouse\u003c/a\u003e is still around and hosting round-the-clock chatrooms.","type":"text","originalIdx":27},{"_id":"I7VUPA5E7NFUTPCKWCNSKTMMQA","additional_properties":{},"content":"Enjoy nonstop scrolling","level":3,"type":"header","originalIdx":28},{"_id":"6HUVQ2TBSBG65OTBIOC3DG57GI","additional_properties":{},"content":"TikTok has elevated mindless scrolling to an art form. If you use Twitter as a way to kill time or unwind, TikTok is the best replacement. You can see similar addictive video content on\u003ca href=\"https://about.instagram.com/features/reels\" target=\"_blank\"\u003e Instagram Reels\u003c/a\u003e, albeit a couple days or weeks later. If your Twitter scrolling is more of a problem than an enjoyable way to pass time, consider \u003ca href=\"https://www.washingtonpost.com/technology/2019/11/26/e-books-libraries-are-huge-hit-leading-long-waits-reader-hacks-worried-publishers/\" target=\"_blank\"\u003echecking out e-books\u003c/a\u003e from your local library to read on your phone instead. You get the same feel of flipping through nonstop text on your screen free, but with less anxiety.","type":"text","originalIdx":29},{"_id":"SYQV7W7YURBD5EQVJRWNPTCIP4","additional_properties":{},"content":"Be smart about trying new apps","level":3,"type":"header","originalIdx":30},{"_id":"COF5X2Y5NNGDHF4X7PC6ACAHYI","additional_properties":{},"content":"When choosing new social networks or apps to test out, don’t blindly trust smaller companies with your data or personal information. Remember that larger alternatives like Facebook and TikTok come with their own ethical and privacy issues. To stay safe, avoid giving apps access to sensitive information like \u003ca href=\"https://www.washingtonpost.com/technology/2021/07/15/contacts-sharing-privacy/\" target=\"_blank\"\u003eyour contacts\u003c/a\u003e (they will ask repeatedly). Check\u003ca href=\"https://www.washingtonpost.com/technology/interactive/2021/privacy-settings-guide/\" target=\"_blank\"\u003e all of your privacy settings\u003c/a\u003e, both in the app on your smartphone’s settings. Sign up with an alias email address and use a \u003ca href=\"https://www.washingtonpost.com/technology/2021/12/16/secure-password-guide/\" target=\"_blank\"\u003estrong password\u003c/a\u003e and multi-factor authentication when you can.","type":"text","originalIdx":31},{"_id":"ERE6EMJ4WNEF3HEZACDF5F6BNI","additional_properties":{},"content":"Stick around but protect your data","level":3,"type":"header","originalIdx":32},{"_id":"DX4UZI2SYNEAZNND7EWNJBPSFE","additional_properties":{},"content":"If you want to wait and see what happens, you can do it while minimizing any potential \u003ca href=\"https://www.washingtonpost.com/technology/2022/01/19/twitter-privacy-settings/\" target=_blank\u003eprivacy risks\u003c/a\u003e posed by new management or a drop in moderation. You can even make yourself a ghost on the app without having to fully leave it.","type":"text","originalIdx":33},{"_id":"KQLH5L2PBJCHRAGFLEUX5WMVHQ","additional_properties":{},"content":"How to lock down your Twitter data, or leave, as Musk takes over","type":"interstitial_link","url":"https://www.washingtonpost.com/technology/2022/04/26/twitter-musk-data-protect/","originalIdx":34},{"_id":"X6WWNWONQVELRBGAE2GVM4LM7M","additional_properties":{},"content":"If you use Twitter anonymously to communicate sensitive information, or worry about online harassment, do these things immediately: Back up all your tweets and follow lists, delete sensitive DMs (both sides have to delete it), delete old tweets, and lock down privacy and anti-harassment settings.","type":"text","originalIdx":35},{"_id":"OU5PYOEYNVEWFLPYZXHCVQZYZI","additional_properties":{},"content":"We walk you through each of these steps \u003ca href=\"https://www.washingtonpost.com/technology/2022/04/26/twitter-musk-data-protect/\" target=_blank\u003ein this guide\u003c/a\u003e. Even if you aren’t worried about your Twitter presence, you should export a copy of your Twitter data now so you have a list of people you follow, before they leave.","type":"text","originalIdx":36}],"content_restrictions":{"content_code":"default"},"credits":{"by":[{"_id":"kellyh","additional_properties":{"original":{"_id":"kellyh","affiliations":"","author_type":"Staff writer","awards":[],"beat":"Technology ","bio":"Heather Kelly is a San Francisco-based reporter covering the ways technology affects everyday life. readabilityObject.title: You’ve decided to quit Twitter. Here’s what you can use to replace it.
readabilityObject.content:
Twitter has a new billionaire owner with big plans. For many loyal users of the 16-year old site, Elon Musk’s takeover is a sign it’s time to use Twitter less or leave it altogether.

The fast-moving feed of news, commentary and arguments has already seen some changes, including a rise in hate speech. Musk has made it clear that he intends to overhaul the site. Massive job cuts and his own position on free speech could lead to more widespread harassment and misinformation. Musk has also suggested that he would allow former president Donald Trump back on the site.

A number of companies are scrambling to fill the potential void. After the sale closed, a surge of people said they were moving to Mastodon, an open-source alternative that has tried to catch on as a less toxic Twitter for years. Mastodon gained 22,139 new accounts this past week and 10,801 in the day after Musk took over, said Mastodon chief executive Eugen Rochko. The site now has more than 380,000 monthly active users, while Twitter has 237.8 million daily active users.

Even if all of Twitter agrees to relocate, there is no one exact copy or one app that will hit all the same spots. As with Facebook, ditching Twitter can mean scattering your online presence across multiple other apps. Leaving Twitter could also mean cutting things out of your online life permanently, like late-night doomscrolling or arguing with strangers online for sport. And maybe, just maybe, that’s okay.

Here are the options you can consider.

Read the news

For many users, Twitter is the place they see the news happening in real time. Instead, put a news aggregation app on the homepage of your phone, like Apple’s News app or Google News. Both include a wide selection of outlets and local news sources, which can be the first to report on events in their areas like shootings or disasters. Switching to traditional news outlets has the added bonus of decreasing the risk of misinformation, which can spread on Twitter during breaking news events.

If you prefer to make your own list of outlets, like you do on Twitter, try an RSS reader. Use an app like Feedly, Newsify or Inoreader. If you specifically enjoy the messy arguments over news stories between regular Twitter patrons, any news publication’s comment section should fill that void.

Get expertise and entertainment

One of the delights of Twitter is that you can read the thoughts of fascinating people for free. Academics, law experts, reporters, comics, and people who have devoted their life to niche topics are all sharing their brilliance in an accessible way. Luckily, many are posting those same thoughts, in more depth, other places.

Sign up for newsletters. Many big Twitter personalities have longer-form offerings, published through their employers or independently on Substack or Medium. You can also support creators on sites like Patreon and Ko-fi, which let you pay different amounts for access to their content. Follow them on the other big social media sites, like Instagram, TikTok, YouTube and LinkedIn. Finally, subscribe to podcasts featuring the same kind of smart, funny and informative people you find on Twitter.

Forge personal relationships

People have found lasting friendships, even fallen in love and gotten married, over Twitter. If you already established relationships with other Twitter users, make sure you have another way to reach them, like WhatsApp, Signal or Instagram. If you have a group of friends, it was probably time to fire up a group chat anyway.

As for making more of these connections, that’s harder. Send emails or direct messages to people whose posts you like on other sites. When you join other sites like Reddit, look for communities of people with similar interests and use direct messages or replies to strike up friendly conversations. Some dating sites have launched platonic versions of their apps specifically for meeting friends, including Bumble BFF, Meetup and Friender.

Be part of a community

To find larger groups of people with similar interests, check out Facebook groups, join subreddits about the topics you’re most interested in, find relevant Discord groups or see if there’s a similar group on Mastodon. You can test out an app called CounterSocial that has a similar feel to Twitter. There’s a high chance all of your interests already have a thriving community on TikTok and YouTube, where you can participate in comments if you’re not into posting videos yourself. If you are trying to find a specific community, look at their last tweets and see if prominent members have said where they’ll be next. If you don’t see the group you want thriving anywhere yet, go ahead and start it yourself.

Get updates in an emergency

Federal and local agencies use Twitter to post updates about emergencies, like road closings from floods, shelter-in-place orders during shootings and evacuation updates for wildfires. You can follow the agencies on Facebook instead, but your best bet is to make sure you are getting alerts pushed directly to you on your phone.

Check your phone settings to see what wireless emergency alerts you’re getting, like Amber Alerts. Subscribe to your school or workplace alert systems, and find local alerts by looking up your state, city or county agencies. A number of them use text-based emergency alert system Nixle (to sign up, text your Zip code to 888777).

Finally, you can dive into the controversial world of neighborhood crime apps, like Citizen and Amazon’s Neighbors app. They let you follow events as they happen in your area with updates from people on the scene, and many local agencies are already on them. (Amazon founder Jeff Bezos owns The Washington Post.)

Do some networking

It seems that for as long as job hunting and corporate jargon exist, LinkedIn will thrive. You’re probably already on LinkedIn, so just give your profile a polish and start posting or sharing what you’re working on there.

Listen to live audio

An exodus from Twitter could be the best thing to happen to Clubhouse, the audio chatroom app that had a moment during the pandemic. Twitter copied Clubhouse with its Twitter Spaces feature, which has been a hit with many users. If you’re leaving Twitter, Clubhouse is still around and hosting round-the-clock chatrooms.

Enjoy nonstop scrolling

TikTok has elevated mindless scrolling to an art form. If you use Twitter as a way to kill time or unwind, TikTok is the best replacement. You can see similar addictive video content on Instagram Reels, albeit a couple days or weeks later. If your Twitter scrolling is more of a problem than an enjoyable way to pass time, consider checking out e-books from your local library to read on your phone instead. You get the same feel of flipping through nonstop text on your screen free, but with less anxiety.

Be smart about trying new apps

When choosing new social networks or apps to test out, don’t blindly trust smaller companies with your data or personal information. Remember that larger alternatives like Facebook and TikTok come with their own ethical and privacy issues. To stay safe, avoid giving apps access to sensitive information like your contacts (they will ask repeatedly). Check all of your privacy settings, both in the app on your smartphone’s settings. Sign up with an alias email address and use a strong password and multi-factor authentication when you can.

Stick around but protect your data

If you want to wait and see what happens, you can do it while minimizing any potential privacy risks posed by new management or a drop in moderation. You can even make yourself a ghost on the app without having to fully leave it.

If you use Twitter anonymously to communicate sensitive information, or worry about online harassment, do these things immediately: Back up all your tweets and follow lists, delete sensitive DMs (both sides have to delete it), delete old tweets, and lock down privacy and anti-harassment settings.

We walk you through each of these steps in this guide. Even if you aren’t worried about your Twitter presence, you should export a copy of your Twitter data now so you have a list of people you follow, before they leave.
